projectHeader.title: Tic Tac Toe – 2 Player Game
projectHeader.subtitle: A clean, responsive, browser-based Tic Tac Toe for two local players. Built with vanilla HTML, CSS and JavaScript — no backend, no AI; two humans share one screen.

projectOverview: This is a lightweight, web-based Tic Tac Toe implementation that allows two human players to play on the same device. It focuses on a polished UI, simple controls for player customization, and robust turn-based game logic implemented entirely in client-side JavaScript.

Players enter their names, can swap X and O before the match starts, and take turns marking a 3x3 grid. The game detects wins (horizontal, vertical, diagonal) and draws, shows visual feedback for the winning line, and presents post-game options to change names, play again (keeping scores), or start a new match (reset scores).

Designed for clarity and responsiveness, the project demonstrates DOM manipulation, state management with plain JS arrays/objects, and CSS-based visual effects — all without any backend or persistence layer.

keyFeatures.title: Player Customization
items: Enter custom names for Player 1 and Player 2 before starting
Toggle/swap X and O icons before the first move

keyFeatures.title: Turn-Based Game Logic
items: Alternates turns and prevents marking an occupied cell
Game state stored in a 9-element array representing the grid
Win detection for all 8 winning combinations (3 rows, 3 columns, 2 diagonals)
Draw detection when all cells are filled without a winner

keyFeatures.title: Post-Game Options
items: Change Names — start a fresh game with new player names
Play Again — rematch using the same players and keep current scores
New Game — rematch with same players but reset scores to zero

keyFeatures.title: User Experience
items: Responsive layout that works on phone and desktop
Visual highlight for the winning line and a clear end-of-game modal

keyFeatures.title: Limitations
items: No AI/computer opponent — strictly human vs human
Game state is not persisted across page refreshes

developmentProcess: Planned a minimal UI: a 3x3 grid, player info panel, and a post-game modal with options.
Implemented game state as an array of 9 values (null / 'X' / 'O'), and wired each cell to an event listener that updates state and the DOM on click.
Created a win-checking function that iterates the 8 winning index combinations and returns the winning line when detected; triggers UI updates and score increments.
Built reusable functions for resetting the board (soft reset), resetting scores (hard reset), and swapping player icons before the first move.
Styled UI responsively with CSS Grid/Flexbox, added small animations for clicks and the winning line, and tested across desktop and mobile viewport sizes.
Tested edge cases: double-clicks, clicking after game end, swapping icons mid-game (blocked), and draw detection.
